titleStmt.title: An Apology To My Lady Cartret.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: writ in Ireland...
A Lady wise as well as fair,
Whose conscience was her only care,
Thoughtfull upon a point of Moment,
Wou'd know the text as well as comment,
Hearing of a grave divine,
She Sent to bid him come and Dine;
Now you must know he was not quite
So grave as to Unpolite,
Thought human Learning wou'd not Lesson
The Dignity of his profession;
And if you heard the man discourse,
You'd like him Ne'er the Worse;
He long had bid the Court farewell,
Retreating silent to his Cell,
Suspected for the Love he bore
For one who Sway'd sometime before,
Wch. made it more surprizing, how
How he shou'd be sent for thither Now.
The message told he Gapes, he Stares,
And scarce beleives his Eyes and Ears,
Cou'd not conceive what it Cou'd mean,
And fain wou'd hear it told, again,
But then the Esqṛ so trim and Nice
T'were rude to make him tell it twice
So bow'd was thankfull for ye Honour,
And wou'd not fail to wait upon her;
His beaver brush'd, his Shoes, & Gown,
Away he trudges into Town;
Passes ye Lower castle Yard,
And Now advancing to the Guard,
He trembles at the thoughts of State,
For Conscious of a Sheepish Gate,
His spirits of a Sudden fail'd him,
He stopp'd & cou'd not tell what Ail'd him;
What was ye Message, I Receiv'd
Why Certainly ye Captain Rav'd,
To dine with her, and come att three
Impossible, it cannot be!
Or may be I've mistook the word!
My Lady──── it must be my Lord!
My Lord's abroad; my Lady too
What must the unhappy Dṛ Do?
Is Captain Crachroad here pray? No.
Nay then tis time for me to go.
Am I awake, or do I dream?
I'm sure he call'd me by my Name:
Nam'd me as plain, as he cou'd Speak;
And yet there must be some Mistake.
Why what a Jest must I have been
Now had my Lady been within,
What cou'd I've said\del·──·add·?\ \del·She'd·thought·me·Mad.·add·I'm mighty Glad\
She went Abroad── She'd thought me Mad
The Hour of dining now is past
Well: then I'll e'en go home & fast,
And since I scap'd being made a scoff
I think I'm very fairly off.
My Lady returning home
Call'd Crachrode is the doctor come?

The Captain walks about & Searches
Through all the Ro\add·o\m\del·e\s & Arches,
Eamines all the Servants round
In vain── No doctor to be found
──My Lady could not chuse but wonder──
Captain I fear you've made some Blunder;
But pray tomorrow go att Ten,
I'll try his manners, once again,
If Rudeness be th\del·e·add·'\ Effect of Knowledge
My Son Shall never see a Colledge;
This Captain was a man of reading
And much good sence as well as breeding.
Who loth to blame, or to Incense,
Said little in his own Defence.
Next day, another Message brought,
The Doctor frighted at his fault,
Is dress'd, & stealing through ye Croud
Now pale as Death, now flush'd, & bow'd,
Panting & faultring── Humm'd & Haw'd
Her Ladyship was gone abroad──
The Captain too── He did not know
Whether he ought to stay or go,
Begg'd she'd forgive him── in conclusion
My Lady pittying his Confusion
Call'd her good Nature to releive him,
om.
And wou'd not only grant his Suit,
But visit\del·ed\ him, & Eat some fruit,
Provided att a proper time
He told the real truth in Rhime
Twas to no purpose to oppose,
She'd hear of no Excuse in prose;
The Doctor stood not on Debate,
Glad to compound att any rate,
So bowing seem'd seemingly comply'd
Thô if he durst he had Deny'd
But first resolv'd to Shew his taste
Was too refind to give a feast,
He'd treat with nothing yṭ was rare
But winding walks & purer Air
He'd entertain without expense
or pride of vain Magnificence,
For well he knew to such a Guest
The plainest meals must be the best
To Stomachs cloy'd with costly fare
Symplicity alone is rare
Whist high & nice & curious Meats
Are really but Vulgar treats
Instead of Spoils of Persian Looms
The costly boast of Regal Rooms,
Thought it more Courtly & Discreet
To Scatter Roses att her feet,
Roses of richest Dye that Shone
With Native Lustre like her Own,
Beauty that needs no Aid of Art
Thrô every Sence to search yẹ Heart,
The Gracious Dame altho She knew
All this was much beneath her Due,
Lik'd every thing, att last thought fit
To praise par maniere Dâquit;
But yet thô seeming Pleas'd cant bear
The Scorching Sun & chilly Air;
Frigh'ted alike att both Extreams
Ill he Displays or hides his Beams,
Thô seeming pleas'd att all She sees
Starts att ye rustling of the Trees,
Can Scarcely Speak for want of Breath
In half a walk fatigu'd to Death;
The Dṛ takes his hint from thence
To vindicate his late offence.
Madam the mighty power of use
Now strongly pleads in my Excuse
If you unus'd have scarcely Strength
To move this Walks uncrouded Length
If ratling in a Scene so rude
Thrô long Disure of Solitude
If long confin'd to fires & skreens
You dread the waving of these Greens,
If trees that neither see nor hear
Nor Speak, nor Walk, can give You fear,
If You who long have breath'd ye fumes
of City Toys & crowded Rooms
Do now Sollicitously Shun
The Cooler Air & Darling Sun,
If Sol's Magestick Eye You flee,
Learn hence t'excuse & pity me,
Consider what it is to bear
The powder'd Courtiers witty Sneer,
To see th'Important man of dress,
Snouching my Colledge Aukerdness
To be the Strutting cornet's Sport
To run the Guantlet of ye Court,
Winning my way by Slow Approaches,
Thrô Crouds of Coxcombs, and of Coaches,
From the first fierce cockaded Centry
Quite thrô the tribe of waiting Gentry;
To pass so many crouded Stages,
And stand ye stairing of ye Pages;
And after all to crown my Spleen
Be told── you are not be seen,
or if you are, be forc'd to bear
The Awe of that Magestick Air;
And can I then be Guilty found
In dreading this vexatious round?
Can it be strange if I Eschew
A Scene so glaring & so New,
Or is he Criminal that flys
The Living Lustre, of your Eyes?
